intro: Smyrnium libanotis, commonly known as the Lebanon cowpea, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its fern-like leaves and yellowish-white flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 1 to 2 meters and thrives in well-drained soils. Its fruits are dry, three-lobed pods that contain small, kidney-shaped seeds. Smyrnium libanotis is often found in rocky or dry habitats and is adapted to arid conditions.
